Executive Summary
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
BC Systems is committed to maintaining a safe work environment. The Plant Engineer for the BC Systems BC Salinas site ensures that safe practices are followed in operations involving hazardous materials. This site has established emergency procedures for ammonia releases. The BC Systems BC Salinas emergency personnel will coordinate with the local Fire Department to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, which include response to emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system covered by this RMP/PSM Program. The site has written evacuation, reporting, and response procedures in place to protect BC Systems employees, the public, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release. 
Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
The BC Systems facility covered by this RMP is to be located at 1341 Merrill Street in Salinas, California. This location will be a produce storage facility (lettuce and spinach) until it is ready for distribution to other locations. 
The regulated substance is Anhydrous Ammonia. One new stationary Ammonia refrigeration system and 3 portable Ammonia refrigeration systems will be used to store produce at various temperatures. The old stationary system described in the previous submission will be removed. These systems are not interconnected. The stationary refrigeration system will have approximately 8,000 pounds of Anhydrous Ammonia. The portable systems will contain approximately 9,000 pounds of Ammonia. Due to the close proximately of the portable and the new stationary Ammonia system, the local Administering Agency, Monterey County Environmental Health Department, has determined that this system should comply with Program Level 3 requirements. BC Systems has previously submitted an RMP/PSM Program on the old stationary and portable systems at this site and this submission is included in Attachment 3.

rst-Case Release Scenario
In this worst-case release scenario, the total Anhydrous Ammonia in the new stationary refrigeration system of approximately 8,000 pounds is assumed to be released within 10 minutes from the high-pressure receiver resulting from a breach of containment. The worst-case release rate would therefore be approximately 800 pounds of Ammonia per minute. 
The release rate is calculated as follows: 
QR = Q/10
Where: QR = Release rate (lbs/min)
 Q = Quantity released (lbs)
Using the scenario criteria:
QR = 8000 lbs / 10 min = 800 lbs/min
No passive mitigation measures were considered to limit the off-site consequence distance for this scenario since the largest vessel is outdoors. The estimated distance to the toxic endpoint for the worst-case release scenario would be 0.5 mile based on R*Comp Software (Version 1.07).

Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Prevention of accidental ammonia releases at BC Systems is accomplished through sound industry practice in the original system design and construction, the specification and review of system modifications prior to their occurrence, and the regular operation, maintenance and monitoring of the system. This includes:
A?    Compliance with industry standards and codes in effect at the time of initial construction of the system, as well as in the event of system modifications through a management of change process.
A?    Performance of a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) at least once every five years using accurate process safety information.
A?    Implementation of operating, maintenance and monitoring procedures. 
A?    Training of system operations and maintenance personnel, as well as ongoing training of the on-site Chemical Response Team. 
A?    Performance of preventive and corrective maintenance according to system component manufacturer recommendations and pursuant to hot work permit program requirements to ensure mechanical integrity.
A?    Application of established auditing, inspection, and pre-start-up review protocols.
A?    Use of qualified contractors for work on the system.
The detailed Prevention Program for this system is contained in a supporting document, which is to be maintained at by the site by the Plant Engineer.
Five Year Accident History
This is a new installation of a stationary ammonia refrigeration system. Therefore, no ammonia releases resulting in on-site or off-site injuries, deaths, or property damag

e, or off-site environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place have occurred from the new stationary system. This site has had one release during the last 5 years. A pipe failure during the change out of a pressure relief valve on an evaporative condenser on a portable unit that is used at this site occurred on 6/04/08 for a total of 72 lbs. Follow up including improved maintenance procedures where implemented following this event. 
Emergency Response Program
This facility has established emergency procedures and coordinates with the local Fire Department to ensure rapid and appropriate response to hazardous material emergencies, which include response to emergencies related to the ammonia refrigeration system covered by this RMP/PSM Program. 
The Emergency Response procedures are accessible at the site, and copies are maintained in the BC Salinas Plant Engineer's files. The document describes response procedures for various emergency scenarios, including the mitigation of hazardous material releases, agency notification procedures in the event of a hazardous material release, and emergency equipment available at the site.
